context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Alec Baldwin's Donald Trump Takes On Puerto Rico's Mayor In The SNL Season Premiere
context_meta.summary: Alec Baldwin is back as President Donald Trump in the Saturday Night Live season premiere, and he lost no time in tackling the president's response to the devastation caused to Puerto Rico by a hurricane. In a cold open skit to start the show, Baldwin returned with his now-legendary Trump impression, while Aidy Bryant as Sarah Huckabee Sanders entered the Oval Office to tell Trump the mayor of San Juan was on the phone to talk about Hurricane Maria. Baldwin told Mayor Carmen Yulín Cruz, played by Melissa Villaseñor, that he knew things were “as the locals say, despacito,” but that it would take several days to get aid to her people: “FEMA takes a few days unless you join FEMA prime,” he said.

text: This show is exposing reality. expressing the insanity of how one party jumps through hoops for the short attention span president defending his insane behavior, while the other party as no voice to speak up at all! Our government is a joke to other countries, maybe by showing it in twisted humor we will get the point, this country is after all, all about Hollywood!

context_meta.title: Poles dressed in black march in defence of women's rights
context_meta.summary: WARSAW (Reuters) - Several thousand Poles dressed in black marched through city streets in Poland on Tuesday in defence of women's rights, on the first anniversary of mass protests against a planned near-total ban on abortion. “We go out because the fight continues,” organisers of the Black Tuesday protest said on social media. “Let them see us, let them hear us, let them know that we are not afraid.” The Warsaw city council said about four thousand people marched in the Polish capital. The protests took place as proponents of a ban on abortions are pushing a draft bill to exclude terminating a pregnancy if the baby is likely to be permanently handicapped. Reporting by Marcin Goettig; Additional

Daoud doesn't seem to know much about Essebsi aside from this. The current president, who spent most of his political career serving under two Tunisian dictators, makes for a peculiar revolutionary. context_meta.author: nanook
context_meta.title: Why is famed women's rights lawyer Lisa Bloom representing Harvey Weinstein?
context_meta.summary: Harvey Weinstein is being assisted in the aftermath of the devastating New York Times expose of sexual harassment allegations by a famed women’s rights lawyer who has taken on Bill Cosby, Donald Trump and Bill O'Reilly. Lisa Bloom, 56, is the daughter of another crusading women’s rights lawyer, Gloria Allred. Following in her mother's footsteps, Ms Bloom has set up a legal practice in Los Angeles and represented Mischa Barton in the “revenge porn” case, and comedienne Kathy Griffin, when she sparked fury by posing with a photo of Mr Trump’s severed head. Her Twitter feed is full of support for women’s rights: promoting model Amber Rose’s “slut walk” demanding respect for women regardless of their clothing, and supporting Blac Chyna, the former girlfriend of Rob Kardashian who accused him of abuse. “Big week at The Bloom Firm, fighting sexual harassment, disability rights, race discrimination, rape, wage and hour cases & more,” she tweeted last month. “Stay tuned!” The Los Angeles-born lawyer’s decision to represent Weinstein as he handles the fallout from the accusations initially appears surprising. But Ms Bloom was already familiar with Weinstein. In April she announced that he had agreed to turn her book on the Trayvon Martin case in to a television mini-series, with the help of Jay Z. BIG ANNOUNCEMENT: My book SUSPICION NATION is being made into a miniseries, produced by Harvey Weinstein and Jay Z! https://t.co/Z4pu7y0TfX— Lisa Bloom (@LisaBloom) April 7, 2017 And Weinstein is a long standing Democrat donor; Ms Bloom was a strong campaigner for Hillary Clinton. She has defended her decision to represent the shamed Hollywood mogul, who has apologised for his behaviour. “As a women’s rights advocate, I have been blunt with Harvey and he has listened to me,” she said. “I have told him that times have changed, it is 2017, and he needs to evolve to a higher standard. I have found Harvey to be refreshingly candid and receptive to my message. He has acknowledged mistakes he has made.” Harvey Weinstein When first contacted about the story, Weinstein replied: “The story sounds so good I want to buy the movie rights.” But the following day, with his legal team including Ms Bloom in place, he issued a contrite statement. “I appreciate the way I’ve behaved with colleagues in the past has caused a lot of pain, and I sincerely apologise for it. Though I’m trying to do better, I know I have a long way to go,” he said. In her own statement, Ms Bloom showed why Weinstein chose her to represent him. “He wants to reach out to any of the women who may have issues with him to talk to them in a respectful, peaceful way, with me present if that is acceptable to them,” she said. “He is deeply bothered by his some of his emotional responses.  “He has been working on his temper for over ten years and is chagrined the issue still plagues him. “He recognises he needs time off to focus on this issue and has much to learn. He wants to reach out to teachers with expertise in this area.” Lisa Bloom, left, with Wendy Walsh - whose accusations of sexual assault toppled Fox News star Bill O'Reilly Her involvement in the case could be seen as a professional risk for someone who has made a name for themselves as the go-to person for women claiming assault. But Ms Bloom was undeterred. “Harvey is not going to demean or attack any of the women making accusations against him, although he does dispute many of the allegations,” she said. “Instead, he is going to use this as a painful learning experience to grow into a better man. I will continue to work with him personally for as long as it takes.” She said that Weinstein had asked her “to do a comprehensive review of his company’s policies and practices regarding women in the workplace.” She added: “I will make recommendations to ensure that gender equality and zero tolerance for workplace misconduct aren’t just goals, but a reality.”

context_meta.author: DeltaBravo
context_meta.title: Women's rights are on the retreat yet again. Why?
context_meta.summary: When modern women are finally fitted with their regulation compulsory chastity belts, dare one dream that they'll come in a range of pretty colours, delightful materials and snazzy designs? The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the National Women's Law Center have announced that they will sue the government over the decision. Apart from the huge amount of money that big business will save, the real target here is sexual autonomy, doubtless all sexual autonomy, but specifically the female kind that a certain mindset has long wanted to control. Contraception, though imperfect, was one of the chief liberators of women, taking much of the fear out of sex.

context_meta.title: The Side of Female Empowerment We Aren't Talking About Enough
context_meta.summary: In 2013, Sheryl Sandberg published her bestselling book Lean In, and gave voice to the discussion of empowering women to lead. For women with professional aspirations, the book encouraged us to jump into the game and take a seat in places where we have not, historically, been welcome. Yes, the 21st Century is certainly a time of opportunity for women. As a professional woman, I am thankful for the way the landscape has changed even in the time since I was a young girl. But, in an age where women are capable of doing anything and everything, does that mean we need to do everything? context_meta.title: feminism fail – Amelia Nagoski, DMA
context_meta.summary: Being a New Englander means I cross state lines a lot. MA, CT, RI, VT, NH, even NY are all “here.” So I get notices and publicity information when local states hold their chapter conferences of the American Choral Directors Association. I've been counting women at ACDA conferences for a few years now, and it's been consistently about 28% women, mostly conducting women's, treble, and children's choirs. So I actually groaned out loud and banged my head on my desk when I saw the featured line-up for the Connecticut ACDA Fall Conference: 0% women in their publicity. Three men conductors and an all-male choral ensemble. Maybe there are also women presenters, but according to publicity, only dudes

context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Justin Trudeau emulates Obama with a feminism essay of his own
context_meta.summary: There's a new model of male Western world leader who proudly proclaims himself a feminist in the pages (or web pages) of a women's magazine. First came President Barack Obama, who penned an essay for Glamour on his last birthday in office in August 2016. His buddy to the north, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, has followed in his footsteps. His essay for MarieClaire.com, “Why I'm Raising My Kids to Be Feminists,” was published on Wednesday in honor of International Day of the Girl. “I am in politics because every day, I get to work to make the world a little better—for my kids, and for yours,” writes Trudeau. He describes his “brilliant, compassionate” 8-year-old daughter Ella-Grace, who

context_meta.author: ipostwhaticareabout
context_meta.title: Raise boys as feminists to change 'culture of sexism', says Justin Trudeau
context_meta.summary: Boys need to be raised to be feminists as much as girls because “our sons have the power and the responsibility to change our culture of sexism”, Justin Trudeau, Canada's prime minister, wrote in an essay published on Wednesday. Teaching boys to be feminists gives them a sense of justice and empathy and helps them “escape the pressure to be a particular kind of masculine” that is damaging to men and those around them, Trudeau writes. Trudeau said he had been thinking about how to raise his daughter, Ella-Grace, as a feminist when his wife, Sophie, reminded him that their sons Xavier and Hadrien needed to be advocates for women as well. “All of us benefit when women and girls have the same opportunities as men and boys – and it's on all of us to make that a reality,” he wrote in an essay for Marie Claire magazine.
